title: 106_hr1926
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bring Them Home Alive Act of 1999" and includes the American Vietnam War POW/MIA Asylum Program. The "Bring Them Home Alive Act of 1999" grants refugee status in the US to eligible aliens from Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, China, or former Soviet Union who deliver a living American Vietnam War POW/MIA. Family members of eligible aliens are also eligible for refugee status. The term "American Vietnam War POW/MIA" refers to individuals who are in a missing status as a result of the Vietnam War, either as a member of a uniformed service or as an employee. It excludes certain individuals. The term "missing status" in relation to the Vietnam War refers to individuals who were serving in Vietnam or Southeast Asia in support of military operations before being officially determined as absent without authority. The Vietnam War is defined as the conflict in Southeast Asia from February 28, 1961, to May 7, 1975. The American Korean War POW/MIA Asylum Program is established. The Attorney General grants refugee status in the US to eligible aliens from North Korea, China, or former Soviet Union who deliver a living American Korean War POW/MIA. Family members of eligible aliens also qualify. The term "American Korean War POW/MIA" refers to individuals who are members of the uniformed services or employees in a missing status as a result of the Korean War, excluding certain cases. The term "Korean War" refers to the conflict on the Korean peninsula from June 27, 1950, to January 31, 1955. "Missing status" in relation to the Korean War is the status of an individual who was serving in Korea or Asia before becoming missing. The term "missing status" in the Korean War refers to individuals who were serving in Korea or Asia before becoming missing. SEC. 4. BROADCASTING INFORMATION ON THE "BRING THEM HOME ALIVE" PROGRAM. The International Broadcasting Bureau is required to promote the "Bring Them Home Alive" refugee program in foreign countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, China, North Korea, Russia, and other former Soviet Union states. They must broadcast a minimum of 20 hours of programming within a 10-day period after the Act's enactment. The International Broadcasting Bureau must broadcast programming for the "Bring Them Home Alive" refugee program for at least 10 hours per quarter for five years after the Act's enactment. Information about the program must be easily accessible on the Bureau's websites. Congress recommends that recipients of federal grants broadcasting to covered countries should provide similar information. The International Broadcasting Bureau, under the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998, is now part of the Broadcasting Board of Governors. SEC. 5. INDEPENDENT STATES OF THE FORMER SOVIET UNION DEFINED as per the FREEDOM Support Act.
